text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. If you've been following the U.S.

presidential election, you know it's been 
a tight race. But it's pretty much over,

and there's one winner: Joe Biden. About 
half the country is happy with the outcome,

and the other half isn't. People react differently 
to winning and losing. There's a lot you can learn

about someone when you watch them compete and 
then see how they handle victory or defeat.

In this lesson, we'll study vocabulary 
related to winning and losing.

Let's start with the basics. "Win" is 
the verb. Who's the person who wins?

The winner. The opposite of winning is losing. 
Who's the person who loses? The loser. "Win"

is also the achievement of winning. It's the 
same thing as a victory. The opposite is a loss.

If you look at any sports team, you'll see their 
record, and you can count their wins and losses.

No one likes to lose, but there are different 
ways to do it. If you lose gracefully,

then you stay in control of your emotions enough 
to congratulate the winner. A sore loser is the

opposite. A sore loser is someone who gets angry 
about losing and then blames others for the loss.

Of course, just because you won, doesn't mean you 
should go around gloating. To gloat means to be

happy with your success in a selfish way to the 
point where you're happy that your opponent lost.

In fact, you enjoy rubbing it in. You want 
to remind your opponent that they lost

and make them feel bad about it. The better 
thing to do is to be a gracious winner.

That's someone who wins, but still 
treats their opponent with respect.

Gracious winners and losers shake hands 
at the end and sincerely say, "Good game."

It's hard to accept defeat when 
you were very close to winning.

The 2020 presidential election in the United 
States was really tight in some states. It's

somewhat easier for the loser to accept the 
outcome when there's a decisive win. To win

decisively means to win clearly, with no 
doubt. A decisive defeat can't be argued.
You can win decisively. You can win easily.

When we talk about how close a competition was, we 
can talk about winning by a large or small margin.

In the case of the presidential elections, 
Biden or Trump won by a large margin in

most states. But in others, it took longer to 
count the votes, and the win was by a narrow or

narrower margin. In other words, fewer 
votes separated the winner from the loser.

From horse racing, we have the expression "to 
win by a nose," meaning not by much. The opposite

is to win by a mile. Another way we can 
say that someone won by a large margin

is to say they won by a landslide. Winning by 
a landslide means that one person received an

overwhelming number of votes. Which of 
these expressions are easier to remember?

Sometimes we can't even talk about the 
margin of victory because there's a tie.

A tie is when both sides do equally well. 
There's no clear winner. In elections,

there can be a runoff election. That's a second 
election to determine the winning candidate.

In the sports world, there are different ways to 
break a tie. In hockey, they go into overtime.

Sometimes there's a shootout. In golf, they 
have a sudden death playoff. That's when

they play hole by hole until one person beats 
the other. Tiebreakers can be really intense.

We talked about gracious 
winners and losers in general.

In sports, we can talk about sportsmanlike 
conduct. If you have this kind of behavior,

then you respect the other team, and you 
treat them fairly both during the game and

at the end. It's good sportsmanship 
to shake hands at the end of the game.

Acknowledging the winner means 
recognizing one's own defeat.

It's not always easy to do, but at 
some point, the loser must concede.
In 2020, this may take longer than usual.

Usually the losing candidate makes a 
phone call and concedes to the winner.

Eventually Trump must concede defeat. He 
must concede the election. He must concede

power to Biden, the President-elect. Will 
there be a concession speech? We'll see.

Some people spend their whole life competing. 
They're very competitive. Through competition,

though, they've probably learned 
that you can't win 'em all.
You simply can't be the winner every time. Right?

You may enjoy a winning streak where you 
have a long series of wins and no losses,

but every professional athlete will tell you that 
all good things come to an end. That's just life.
You win some, you lose some. So the saying goes.

There's a lot to be learned from competition. 
First place is nice, but there are worse things

to lose, like losing face. "To lose face" 
means to lose respect and status. You're

publicly humiliated. If you're caught lying 
and cheating, for example, you'd lose face.

In games, we play to win, of course, but we also 
play to have fun. Agreed? Sometimes, though,

winning isn't the most important thing. 
It's more about what we're fighting for.

When celebrities go on game shows, for instance, 
they play to win money for a charity. Even if

they lose, they receive a small sum of money 
to donate to the charity of their choice.
They also play to raise awareness for their cause.

They say that our attitude influences our chances 
of success, and I agree with that. We need to be

positive. Sometimes, however, I think we secretly 
know we're fighting a losing battle. This means

that we understand no matter how hard we try, we 
won't likely succeed, but we keep trying anyway.

This can be in a competition with others or in our 
individual lives, where we set goals and work hard

to achieve them. One setback after the other can 
make us feel like we're fighting a losing battle.

Quiz time! Let's see how well you remember 
the words and expressions from this lesson.

One. What do we call someone who gets angry 
about losing? A sore loser. Two. What's the

action about being selfishly happy about your 
victory and someone else's defeat? Gloating.

Three. Instead of rubbing it in, you can be a 
nice winner. What kind of winner can you be?
A gracious winner.

Four. What are two other ways to say 
that someone won by a large margin?
Win by a landslide and win by a mile.

Five. What's another way to say 
that someone won by a narrow margin?
Win by a nose.
Six. When there's a tie, what must we have?
A tie breaker.

Seven. If you have sportsmanlike 
conduct, what do you show?
Good sportsmanship.
Eight. Who makes a concession speech?
The loser. The loser must concede.

Nine. When you lose respectability, 
what else do you lose?
You lose face.

Ten. When you try without much success or 
without hope of success, what are you fighting?
A losing battle.

And here's one bonus question. What 
does every sports team want to enjoy?
That long series of wins?
A winning streak.

We'll end here. Please like and share the 
video if you found it useful and interesting.
As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and 
Instagram. And don't forget to subscribe!
Turn on those notifications.
